item.title: By: Steve
item.dc:creator: Steve
item.description:
Yes you are right! Awk is brilliant if you need to work on columns and rows. It's a little bit like SQL in that it's not a procedural approach. That line is a complete awk program - many are that small. They are of the form of multiple
Pattern { action }
which are applied to each line (row) so when pattern matches action is performed. $ is used to reference columns from $1 to $NF (last - I've no idea why NF).
~ means match regex. A = would be an exact match. !~ is doesn't match.
Thus it boils down to - when the the 1st column ($1) matches 1st char is not a 'd' ([^d]) and last is a 'x'(x$) then print "/system"/<filename in last column>.
See https://www.gnu.org/software/gawk/manual/gawk.html
Note in regex [] set letters are literal so [^d] is "not d" and not 'digit'.
You might be right - restricting .* could be better but I think $ sorts it out as it as * is maximal match in awk (I hope) ;)
Hth.

item.title: By: AndrÃ© Jaenisch
item.dc:creator: AndrÃ© Jaenisch
item.description:
Hello, Steve,
thanks for permitting my comment.
Could you break the awk command down? I'm familiar to RegEx, but awk is ... well awkward to me.
From what I understand, <code>awk '$1 ~ /^[^d].*x$/ {print "/system/" $NF}'</code> splits the line at whitespace, fetches the first field (the line with e.g. <code>drwxrwxrwx</code> displaying the permission flags for user/group/others), looks for something beginning (^) with no digit ([^d]), followed by an arbitrary set (.*) of characters (why not restricting?) ending on x (x$) and then prints the match after a "/string/".
Am I right? What does ~ do here?
Regards,
AndrÃ©

item.title: By: Steve
item.dc:creator: Steve
item.description: AndrÃ© Thank you for taking the time to comment. 2 points here. 1) It's not all files - just those marked executable in the .tar.gz archive (that's what awk is doing) 2) I did adb shell ls -l to see what they were set to on the device when flashed from linux and I got 777 I agree it seems a bit rash.
item.content:encoded:
AndrÃ© Thank you for taking the time to comment. 2 points here.
1) It’s not all files – just those marked executable in the .tar.gz archive (that’s what awk is doing)
2) I did adb shell ls -l to see what they were set to on the device when flashed from linux and I got 777
I agree it seems a bit rash.
